title: Bayern Munich vs PSG live updates : Champions League predicted line - ups , team news and start time
body_text:
Advertisement
How Bayern Munich beat PSG 2-0 to advance to Champions League quarter-finals
Summary
Bayern Munich have beaten Paris Saint-Germain 2-0 in the second leg of their Champions League round of 16 tie, advancing to the quarter-finals 3-0 on aggregate.
The French side had a golden opportunity to level the tie in the first half as Yann Sommer lost the ball in his own box, but Matthijs de Ligt made an incredible goal-line clearance to prevent Vitinha from scoring.
Eric Maxim Choupo-Moting doubled the hosts' aggregate advantage in the 61st minute. It was Marco Verratti's turnover in his own box this time that created the chance, and Bayern made sure to punish their opponents.
Serge Gnabry sealed the win with his goal in the 89th minute, finishing off a blistering counter-attack.
Bayern advance to the last eight for the fourth straight season, while PSG are eliminated at this stage for the second year in a row.
Nagelsmann: 'We deserved to win'
Julian Nagelsmann has spoken to the media following the win: "In the first half, we didn't do what we had talked about before very well. There was too much space.
"But we defended better in the second half and were dangerous on the ball. In the end, we deserved to win.
"If we show maximum hunger with emotion and we couple that with our quality, then we can achieve anything."
Galtier: Bayern's first goal was 'ridiculous'
Christophe Galtier had more to say following the loss: "We did not manage to score when we were on top of things.
"Then we concede a ridiculous goal. What made the difference is the fact we missed some key players in both legs. It's a big disappointment but we have to swallow it."
Galtier on his future at PSG
Christophe Galtier has spoken about his future at PSG: “It’s really too early to talk about it. It depends on the management and my president. There’s a disappointment.
“The club had a lot of hopes for this competition. I stay focused on the end of the season”.
Donnarumma: 'We are angry'
Gianluigi Donnarumma has spoken to Sky Sports: “We are disappointed, we are angry. It’s very disappointing to go out of the Champions League.
“I have no regrets or doubts on my choice to join Paris Saint-Germain. Never had doubts."
On whether he's happy that his former club AC Milan have advanced: "Yes, but I’m so proud to be at PSG."
Musiala: 'We can win this tournament'
Jamal Musiala has spoken to BT Sport: "I think we showed intensity throughout the whole game. We started the second half strongly.
"We didn't let them have time on the ball in the final third. Lionel Messi, Kylian Mbappe, we know what they're capable of. We controlled the game better. Overall it was a good game for us.
"We went through some tactical things to change up a bit (at half-time). We had to up our intensity. When we do that we're very difficult to beat.
"(De Ligt's goal-line clearance) brought us to life. Those little moments are key.
"We all have the mentality we can win this tournament. We just have to take it game by game."
On Eric Maxim Choupo-Moting: "It's very fun to play with him. He's a goal threat and has the presence in the box we need. He's an amazing player. He has the quality we need up front. He's a good friend as well. He's a good guy."
A word for Musiala
Jamal Musiala was everywhere tonight, completing eight dribbles in this match.
Since dribbles have been tracked starting in 2003-04, no Bayern Munich player has ever completed more in a Champions League knockout stage game.
Defence the difference
Bayern Munich have now kept seven clean sheets in eight Champions League matches this season. Remarkably, the lone side to score against them has been Viktoria Plzen, who did so in a 4-2 win for Bayern in the Czech Republic.
PSG, meanwhile, failed to keep a single clean sheet across their eight matches this season, the first time they've done so in this competition.
Fortress Allianz Arena
Bayern Munich have now won 16 of their past 18 Champions League home games (D1 L1).
PSG did account for the sole loss during that time, in the 2021 quarter-finals, but they couldn't repeat that feat today.
The first leg was crucial
Bayern Munich have now advanced 21 of 23 times they won the first leg of a Champions League knockout tie.
The two exceptions came against Real Madrid in 2002 and against Inter Milan in 2011.
PSG, on the other hand, have only advanced once in six times they lost the first leg of a UCL knockout tie - against Borussia Dortmund in 2020.
PSG can't get over the hump
In stark contrast to Bayern's regular spot in the final eight, this is the fifth time in the last seven seasons that PSG have been eliminated at this stage.
That's at least two more times than any other side during that period.
Old hat
Bayern Munich have qualified for the Champions League quarter-finals for the 21st time.
No other club has reached the final eight as many times.
Video of Gnabry's clinching goal - US readers
Our American readers can check out the replay of the final goal here:
Video of Gnabry's clinching goal - UK readers
Our British readers can check out the replay of the final goal here:
PSG fall short yet again
Paris Saint-Germain have been knocked out of the Champions League once again.
Matt Woosnam has looked back at some of PSG's previous failures in the competition, cataloguing five additional times they fell short.
Check out his report below.
Half of the last eight is set
We now know four of the eight teams that will comprise the Champions League quarterfinals:
- Chelsea
- Benfica
- Bayern Munich
- AC Milan
They'll be joined by four of these eight teams:
- Manchester City and RB Leipzig are tied 1-1
- Real Madrid lead Liverpool 5-2
- Napoli lead Eintracht Frankfurt 2-0
- Inter Milan lead Porto 1-0
AC Milan advance, Tottenham eliminated
AC Milan vs Tottenham in London has finished 0-0, meaning the Italian side have progressed to the quarter-finals 1-0 on aggregate.
Joy and dejection
The final images at the Allianz Arena tell their own story. Jubilant scenes in the Bayern end, a team united and they celebrate what became a comfortable victory.
Meanwhile, Mbappe vanishes from the field immediately, followed by Messi. In the end, just no more than five or six players, led by Marquinhos, head over to acknowledge the travelling PSG support.
There’s no denying that the Vitinha chance and the injuries to PSG defenders played a part, but Bayern had so much more to their game in the end, including on the substitutes bench. Their class showed through, and they progress as deserved winners.
(All photos by Getty Images)
FT: Bayern are through!
It's all over in Munich! PSG's quest for the ultimate trophy drags on.
Could that be Lionel Messi's final Champions League appearance?
Bayern's defence has been vital
90+4' Bayern Munich 2-0 Paris Saint-Germain
(Bayern lead 3-0 on aggregate)
Moments before the goal, Bayern pulled off two vital challenges.
Upamecano provided the first to halt Hakimi, and then Davies pulled off a fabulous tackle to stop Mbappe when certain to score.
Prevented a nervy ending.
